file_metadata.title: Computational discovery and in vivo validation of hnf4 as a regulatory gene in planarian regeneration

chunks.text: Automated computational methods can infer dynamic regulatory network models from experimental data, offering a powerful approach to understanding planarian regeneration. A recent computational method reverse-engineered a mechanistic model of planarian regeneration, recapitulating key anterior-posterior patterning experiments. Validating this model with novel experiments would enhance our understanding of planarian regeneration and demonstrate the power of this automated methodology.
chunks.chunk_summary: Computational methods can reverse-engineer models of planarian regeneration, and validating these models with new experiments strengthens our understanding of the process.

chunks.text: Using the Michigan Molecular Interactions and STRING databases and MoCha software, an unknown regulatory gene predicted by the model was identified as hnf4. The model predicted that RNAi of hnf4 would rescue the tailless phenotype caused by RNAi of hh. In vivo experiments validated these predictions, demonstrating hnf4's role in planarian regeneration and the predictive power of the model.
chunks.chunk_summary: Hnf4 was identified as a regulatory gene in planarian regeneration, and its predicted role in rescuing the tailless phenotype caused by hh RNAi was experimentally validated.

chunks.text: These results confirm hnf4 as a regulatory gene in planarian regeneration, validate the computational predictions of the reverse-engineered dynamic model, and demonstrate the potential of this automated methodology for discovering novel genes, pathways, and experimental phenotypes.
chunks.chunk_summary: The findings validate the computational model and highlight its potential for discovering new genes and pathways involved in planarian regeneration.

chunks.text: Planarian worms exhibit remarkable regenerative abilities, but understanding the mechanisms behind their head-trunk-tail pattern restoration is challenging due to complex regulatory networks. While extensive experimental data exists, there's a lack of comprehensive mechanistic models that can explain multiple aspects of planarian regeneration simultaneously.
chunks.chunk_summary: Despite extensive data, understanding the complex regulatory networks governing planarian regeneration remains a challenge, hindering the development of comprehensive mechanistic models.

chunks.text: Computational methods offer a promising approach to reverse-engineer dynamic models directly from experimental data, providing a way to build systems-level models that can mechanistically explain complex biological processes like regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Computational methods offer a powerful approach to reverse-engineer dynamic models of complex biological processes like regeneration, providing mechanistic explanations for observed phenomena.

chunks.text: A recently reverse-engineered dynamic model of planarian regeneration successfully recapitulated various experimental phenotypes in silico. This model predicted the existence of unknown regulatory genes crucial for regeneration. Identifying these genes would enhance our understanding of planarian regeneration and validate the model and the computational approach.
chunks.chunk_summary: A reverse-engineered dynamic model of planarian regeneration predicted the existence of unknown regulatory genes, whose identification would validate the model and advance our understanding of the process.

chunks.text: This study aims to uncover new biological signaling and predict experimental outcomes using the model. The discovery of hnf4 as a planarian regulatory gene and its predicted ability to rescue a tailless phenotype are presented. These predictions were tested in vivo, validating the model's predictions.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study uses a computational model to predict the role of hnf4 in rescuing a tailless phenotype in planarians, and these predictions are validated through in vivo experiments.

chunks.text: Asexual Schmidtea mediterranea (CIW4) planarians were cultured in specific conditions and starved before experiments. Double-stranded RNA interference (RNAi) experiments involved dsRNA generation and injection, followed by amputation into head, pharynx, and tail regions.  Regenerated fragments were monitored and imaged.
chunks.chunk_summary: Planarians were cultured, subjected to RNAi, amputated, and their regeneration monitored.

chunks.text: Images of regenerated fragments were collected and analyzed using Zeiss Stemi SV 6 dissecting microscope and Canon EOS Rebel T3i DSLR camera. Measurements were performed on fully extended worms. Adobe Photoshop and Matlab scripts were used to categorize and quantify pixel areas belonging to head, trunk, and tail regions, including blastemas, for statistical analysis.
chunks.chunk_summary: Images of regenerated planarians were analyzed using image processing software to quantify the areas of different body regions.

chunks.text: A previously reverse-engineered model predicted an unknown regulatory gene, regulated by β-catenin and hh, necessary for planarian regeneration. Using MiMI and MoCha, this gene was identified as HNF4A in other species, with a planarian homolog, hnf4, expressed in intestinal cells, neoblasts, and involved in intestinal regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: An unknown regulatory gene predicted by the model was identified as hnf4, a homolog of HNF4A found in other species and involved in planarian intestinal regeneration.

chunks.text: The model predicted morphological outcomes of single and double knockdowns of hnf4, β-catenin, and hh in amputated trunk pieces.  Single hnf4 knockdown resulted in wild-type morphology. Double knockdown of β-catenin and hnf4 resulted in a double-head, while double knockdown of hh and hnf4 predicted a wild-type morphology, rescuing the tailless phenotype of hh knockdown.
chunks.chunk_summary: The model predicted that hnf4 knockdown would rescue the tailless phenotype caused by hh knockdown.

chunks.text: In vivo RNAi experiments validated the in silico predictions. Single hnf4 RNAi resulted in wild-type morphology, β-catenin RNAi in double-head morphology, and hh RNAi in tailless morphology. Double RNAi of β-catenin and hnf4 resulted in double-head morphology, while double RNAi of hh and hnf4 restored wild-type morphology, confirming hnf4's rescue of the hh knockdown phenotype.
chunks.chunk_summary: In vivo experiments confirmed the model's predictions, showing that hnf4 RNAi rescues the tailless phenotype caused by hh RNAi.

chunks.text: Statistical analysis of regenerated tail area ratios confirmed the in vivo observations.  No significant difference was found between control and hnf4 RNAi, while hh RNAi produced significantly smaller tails. Double hh and hnf4 RNAi tail areas were not significantly different from controls but were significantly larger than hh RNAi alone, validating hnf4's rescue effect.
chunks.chunk_summary: Statistical analysis confirmed that hnf4 RNAi rescues the reduced tail size caused by hh RNAi.

chunks.text: This study computationally discovered and experimentally validated hnf4 as a regulatory gene in planarian regeneration. Using databases and tools, hnf4 was identified based on model predictions. The model accurately predicted the morphological outcomes of single and double knockdowns of hnf4 and its interactors, revealing hnf4's ability to rescue the tailless phenotype caused by hh knockdown.
chunks.topic: Hnf4 regulatory role and model validation
chunks.chunk_summary: The study validated hnf4 as a regulatory gene in planarian regeneration, confirming the model's predictions about its role in rescuing the tailless phenotype.

chunks.text: In vivo experiments confirmed the model's predictions, demonstrating that hnf4 RNAi rescues the tailless phenotype caused by hh RNAi. Statistical analysis further supported these findings. The dynamic nature of the model provides a mechanistic explanation for the observed morphologies under different perturbations.
chunks.topic: In vivo validation and mechanistic explanation
chunks.chunk_summary: In vivo experiments and statistical analysis validated the model's predictions, and the model's dynamic nature provides a mechanistic explanation for the observed phenotypes.

chunks.text: The model explains the observed phenotypes based on the interplay between hh and hnf4 in regulating tail and trunk signals.  The different knockdown scenarios affect the balance of these signals, leading to the observed morphological outcomes, including the rescue of the tailless phenotype by hnf4 RNAi.
chunks.chunk_summary: The model explains the observed phenotypes based on the interplay between hh and hnf4 in regulating tail and trunk signals, with hnf4 RNAi rescuing the tailless phenotype by restoring the balance of these signals.

chunks.text: Computational approaches are crucial for building predictive models of complex biological phenomena and understanding regulatory networks. Reverse-engineered models can generate testable predictions, including novel regulatory elements and experimental phenotypes. This study validated the predictions of a planarian regeneration model, discovering hnf4 as a regulatory gene and its ability to rescue an abnormal phenotype.
chunks.chunk_summary: Computational approaches are essential for building predictive models and understanding regulatory networks, as demonstrated by the validation of a planarian regeneration model and the discovery of hnf4's regulatory role.

chunks.text: Future work will focus on validating the second unknown regulatory gene predicted by the model, preliminarily characterized as the Frizzled family of receptors.  Further regulatory elements are needed to control other aspects of tail regeneration, and incorporating these into the model will lead to more detailed and comprehensive models.
chunks.chunk_summary: Future work will validate another predicted gene and incorporate additional regulatory elements to refine the model and address other aspects of tail regeneration.

chunks.text: This work demonstrates a pipeline for converting computationally discovered models into testable hypotheses, highlighting the power of automated reverse-engineering methods for discovering mechanistic models of developmental and regenerative biology. Interaction databases and their confidence scores are valuable resources for characterizing unknown elements predicted by these models.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study demonstrates a pipeline for using computational models to generate testable hypotheses and highlights the value of interaction databases for characterizing predicted elements.
